newsitem.title: INDIA: Bombay shares end down, lacklustre trade.
newsitem.headline: Bombay shares end down, lacklustre trade.

text.p: Bombay shares posted losses in dull trade on Monday, with a majority of blue-chip stocks ending lower, dealers said.
"Trading was very dull. There is hardly any action in the market," said Ketan Jhaveri, chief dealer at Kotak Securities.
He said the market was likely to fall further, unless local institutions started bidding agressively.
The 30-share index of the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) closed 56.36 points, or 1.79 percent, lower at a provisional 3,092.1, against the day's high of 3,143.89.
ITC Ltd fell 11.50 rupees or 3.84 percent to 287.50 rupees with sellers dominating action in the counter, dealers said.
"People have still not recovered from the arrests of officials," Jhaveri said.
Shares of ITC have plunged 10 percent in less than a week, pounded by news of a foreign exchange scandal, which was "to the tune of over $100 million," according to the Finance Ministry.
Last week, India's Enforcement Directorate searched the firm's offices and arrested senior officials including two former chairmen.

"The enormity and scale of this development, coupled with the fact that many senior management personnel may be involved, tremendously increases the risk profile of the company," analyst Rukhshad Shroff at Jardine Fleming India Broking said in a report.
The 500-share CRISIL index lost 8.86 points or 1.5 percent to end at a provisional 596.77.
SBI lost 8.75 rupees to 218.50 rupees, TISCO 4.75 to 172.0, Reliance 5.50 to 189.0, ACC 50.20 to 1,458.0, Bajaj Auto 19.20 to 929.25, MTNL 4.50 to 221.75 and M&M 6.25 to 309.25.
